verb.description: Point or direct (a weapon or camera) at a target.
examples: aim the camcorder at some suitable object
aim for the middle of the target
we aim to give you the best possible service
new French cooking aims at producing clear, fresh flavors and light textures

noun.description: A purpose or intention; a desired outcome.
examples: our primary aim is to achieve financial discipline

noun.description: The directing of a weapon or object at a target.
examples: his aim was perfect, and the guard's body collapsed backward

abbreviation.description: Alternative Investment Market (a subsidiary market of the London Stock Exchange that allows small companies to be traded without the expense of a full market listing).

phrases: I won't make any rash predictions, but we will be aiming high.
You must aim high - Irish firms must try to be the very best in our globalised world, said Mr. Cronin.
It's not a great film, but it leaves you with some great moments and aims high.
The veteran defender said: I'm sure the club will be aiming high, especially after the euphoria of promotion last year.
One who aims high for the future must not be concerned with present loss or gain.
origin: Middle English: from Old French amer, variant of esmer (from Latin aestimare assess, estimate), reinforced by aemer, aesmer (from late Latin adaestimare, intensified form of aestimare).
